Fox in Flocks is devoted to the art, design, and creatives in the life of its producer, Kay Christensen.

 

Contact her at kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Home
item.content:encoded:
vasuma eyewear

collaboration with lagom

Vasuma Eyewear is a collection of unisex glasses, both sun- and ophthalmic. 
The overall theme for the collection is that here in Sweden bullies make
fun of others wearing glasses by calling them “Eyewear snake”. This is 
a collaboration together with Lagom Studios.

item.title: Saft ("Juice")
item.content:encoded:
So thirsty.

When I woke up this morning I was really craving grapefruit juice. I don't know why. The water here tastes bad to me, so I'm probably dehydrated from too much instant coffee combatting my jet lag and not enough water. So after having more instant coffee I took a jaunt around the corner to the supermarket.

Found the selection. There was aeble ("apple") saft, appelsin (not apple but "orange") saft, roed ("red") something-or-other saft, multi-saft (fruit punch?), more safts than there are fruits I think, and finally voila! pink grape ("grapefruit") saft. The grapefruit juice was in a tall, skinny glass bottle and looked more like martini mix than juice.

I bought it and in my thirst starting drinking it on the walk back to my apartment. I probably looked like an alcoholic. And all the more strange because Danes seem not to eat or drink while in transit.

Chug, chug. It tastes like 1 part grape saft to 4 parts sugar. I've been wondering what it's like to drink hummingbird nectar, and now I know.

UPDATE: After drinking 2/3 of the bottle today, I finally noticed the part that says "fortyndes 1:5 = 3 liter." I'm supposed to be diluting this in water. I just drank 2 liter's worth of grapefruit juice concentrate.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Danish
item.content:encoded:
Danish is pretty much just a mix of German and English. Like in German, word construction is logical, and the grammar is even more straightforward. And it's especially easy to pick up the written language because most public-facing items are printed in both Danish and English.

The only problem is the spoken version. Danes take a lot of shortcuts when pronouncing words: in particular, they drop hard consonant sounds made by "d"s and "g"s in the middle of words. And seemingly straightforward combinations of vowels lead to crazy diphthongs that my Chinese expat host says you just have to memorize. Combine these facts with a sing-song delivery and you get a mumbly, loopy, guttural-in-surprising-places language that only sometimes sounds like German.

My favorite words so far are muldvarp ("mole")--because it seems to fit the animal's weirdness--and grundstoffer ("elements"; literally "ground stuff" or "basic stuff") because its literalness makes the entire Danish population seem grounded in scientific rationale.

BTW, I just looked up the translations of muld and varp: taken really literally it's "soil warp."
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Velkommen til Koebenhavn! Now get the damn bus.
item.content:encoded:
On the fifth day, Kay did ride the struggle bus.

 

Spoiler alert: This is a pretty looong post about how I couldn't figure out how to get where I needed to go. It might be totally boring, but I tell it at length because of how many stupid decisions I made.

 

My flight touched down in Copenhagen at 10:50 AM local time. My Airbnb is a 30-minute bus ride directly from the airport. I arrived there at 1:20 PM--2.5 hours after landing.

Why the delay? Oh, it wasn't luggage since I hadn't checked any baggage. It just took me more than two hours to figure out how to get a bus ticket at the airport.

I knew exactly which bus and even which bus stop I needed, but I'd been so relaxed about European travel before my trip that I hadn't bothered to research Copenhagen's public transportation or, usually more importantly, how to purchase it. So when I passed a single bus/metro/train ticket machine in the baggage area at the airport, I stopped there for my first attempt. Examining the area for literature on bus routes, I found only a bunch of identical pamphlets with very ambiguous-looking maps that looked more like metro routes than bus lines--but who could tell (in retrospect, "S-Train" is obviously a rail system because it has the word "train" in it, but in my jet lag and minor panic I thought it might be a cute name for buses)?

I waited in the long line (Why is there only ONE ticket machine?? That's not suspicious at all, Kay.) and noticed as I approached the machine that there was a tiny, essentially illegible map on the machine itself that everyone was clamoring up against to try to decipher. Not only was it too small, but the map legend made absolutely no sense AND was written in pastel colors that couldn't be seen by any human eye. Well, let's try to get a ticket anyway and see what happens.

The bus and metro in Copenhagen, like in many other cities, operates on a zone system. After not finding my bus stop written in any of the zones on the terrible minuscule machine map, I just blindly picked one (Zone 2 sounded good) and put my credit card into the machine. This marked the beginning of my very slow revelation that all card transactions, even credit, in Copenhagen require a PIN. But I didn't know that at the time, and nothing I pressed would cancel the transaction. I made up a PIN just for fun. Eventually the ticket machine spit out my card and started the ticket process over without any warning. By then a rather quietly anxious line of people had gathered behind me, so I made a sad audible joke and wandered away from the machine to do some more research.

Next problem: no free Wifi in the Copenhagen airport. Indeed, I would later realize that I can't get 4G (not even 3G!!) wireless anywhere in Copenhagen either. Luckily, I had saved a PDF of the bus schedule I needed, but that still didn't save me from having to buy a ticket. I finally waited in the "Arrivals Assistance" line and was told by the very nice bilingual man behind the counter that if I'd just exit the baggage claim area, I'd find an ENTIRE TERMINAL'S WORTH OF TRAIN TICKET MACHINES AND TRAIN TICKET LINES FROM WHICH TO GET HELP. And he was correct.

After initially going the wrong way (this happened, like, six times for no good reason) I found the ticket area and got in line, asked for what I needed, and was given a paper ticket and told where to go for the bus. In my happiness at being handed a bus ticket I was celebrating in my head and didn't catch where the woman had told me to wait for the bus. So I followed a sign that said "Bus to Terminal 1" (really clearly not the bus that goes into town, but I kept trying to convince myself of totally illogical things) and ended up at the Metro area, where a translated sign announced that the train was delayed due to a "person collision." I realized this was not the right place and went back to the beginning, where I saw the bus stop that I wanted just outside.

And huzzah! The 5A bus pulled up within a few minutes of my waiting. But at the last moment, I looked at my ticket and realized that it said "Zone: 003" when I really needed to get to Copenhagen's city, in Zone 1. So I neglected to board the bus (could've asked the driver--everyone's bilingual--but thought I should take the more difficult route) and went back to the ticket line to ask my lady about the zone. Turns out that "Zone" does't indicate the destination zone; it tells how many zones you can pass through. Copenhagen's airport is in Zone 4, and I needed Zone 1, so 003 was indeed the correct thing. (Why does the zone number have three digits? The largest difference in zones you'll ever get is still just one digit. This is confusing.)

Jesus. Get on the bus. Find that it's a nice bus and works exactly like any other city's bus. Sit down for a while.

I successfully got off at my stop, Klaksvigsgade. At that point I had planned to use Google Maps to get exact directions to my Airbnb. But surprise! No internet in the city. I wandered in the direction that looked like some of the pictures I saw on the Airbnb page and found no Klaksvigsgade street. Turning around, I wandered back the other way. Still no luck. Finally, across a large two-direction street I saw a street I thought I would try.

I was almost there! No problems!

But I couldn't for the life of me figure out where to cross the damn street. There were no pedestrian zones, and I didn't want to get run over by either the cars or the masses of bicycles in both directions. I finally saw a pedestrian tunnel underneath the bridge I was standing on, but DAMN, it was closed for repairs.

After a few more minutes of me wandering back and forth without thinking, I finally found a second pedestrian tunnel under the bridge a bit farther away and successfully arrived on the other side of the avenue. And Klaksvigsgade it was!

Got up to my Airbnb and met one of the two hosts, Rei. He's a Chinese ex-pat who has been living in Copenhagen for a decade now, and he speaks Mandarin, English, and Danish essentially fluently. What a welcome reception, and an awesome room, I received.

Thank god. After all the time on the struggle bus, I needed a nap.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: On the third day
item.content:encoded:
On the third day, Kay did take care of business.

Nothing much happened on the third day, since I had to take a meeting and dog Kaiser Permanente about my insurance application again. Also Muni.

In the evening I left Becca's house for JFK, and the only real highlight was the number of Danes and Germans in the security line with me. I immediately felt at home among the blond-haired, blue-eyed, tailored-trousered, designer-glassesed group, despite not understanding anything of the Danish and only a little of the German.

My direct flight to Copenhagen was on a Dreamliner! It was nice. The windows have electric tinting rather than shades, the entertainment screens actually have good UX design, and the colored lighting shows on the ceilings--coordinated with takeoff, landing, and general flight--are entertaining if not actually biologically helpful.

Last note: I flew Norwegian Air Shuttle. The flight crew, nearly all female, wore red leather gloves and prim pillbox hats for takeoff and landing. They took these off during the flight to make for more regular uniforms. They, like pretty much everyone I've met in Copenhagen so far, were all bilingual. It was a good flight.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Copenhagen by Night
item.content:encoded:
I spent my last night in Copenhagen wandering and taking pictures. Here.

Okay, a few bonus pictures from the day wandering.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: On the first day
item.content:encoded:
On the first day, Kay flew into New York's JFK Airport.

 

The flight went by quickly. On my left sat a large Canadian mountain man--someone from north of Toronto who had the ice fishing pictures to prove it--who was returning with his brother from the Hardly Strickly bluegrass festival in SF. He was immediately genial. I've come to expect this from Canadians. On my right was a young guy in Beats who spent the flight seamlessly transitioning among iPad, iPhone, and laptop. He had a tattoo on the back of his neck that read "Enough Is Enough" but I'm not sure he was thinking about it. Both guys were immediately predictable, which convinced me right away that the flight would be easy. I get nervous about flying only when I'm not sure how the people next to me will behave.

Sitting in the row in front of me were three septuagenarians who, I hate to admit it, provided the comic relief during the flight. It started when Window Seat Man arrived after Aisle Husband and Middle Wife had already managed to lower themselves stiffly into their seats. Window Seat, looking remarkably like an older version of George Costanza's dad, pointed to his seat and announced that

"Unfortunately, I'm going to have to ask you to get up."

Aisle and Middle asked if he meant that he was sitting there.

"Unfortunately," he replied and sighed while Aisle and Middle looked skeptical that they would enjoy their trip.

Halfway through the flight, Window asked the others to get out so he could use the bathroom; it then took him TWO INCREASINGLY INTENSE MINUTES to put away his things, stow his tray table, unbuckle his seatbelt, and raise himself into a standing position. The standing part was a whole minute by itself. Meanwhile, Aisle stood in the aisle with the blankly pleasant look of a man who can no longer hear anything, and Middle gave Window the evil eye and internally mused about killing him. (Middle had her own quirk, which was to sneeze--a melodramatic, stentorian sneeze--any time her husband got up to use the bathroom, about once an hour.)

Window Seat Man's zenith, though, was at the end of the flight when he played several classical music snippets from his laptop, but seemed not to be able to diagnose that the audio was coming through his laptop speakers rather than the earbuds in his ears. Middle definitely wanted to kill him. Aisle was still pleasantly unaware.

Delta has new seat placards designed to make it clearer which row you're in and which seat letter is window vs. aisle. They're new but not fantastic, so I spent some flight time doodling and redesigning them.

Taking the AirTran from JFK and then transferring to the LIRR was fun. I'd forgotten how much I love cities and trains. After much Google Mapping (no recall of how much I used to have to plan/print before smart phones and Google Maps) I arrived at the Queens apartment of an old friend, Becca.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Davids Samling ("The David Collection")
item.content:encoded:
And this one deserved its own post.

 

As I mentioned in the previous post, the David Collection had some of the best museum design I've ever seen. Some notable patterns:

Rich, bright wall colors picked to contrast with the color themes in the displayed pieces and with each other. (I haven't enhanced the photos yet, so imagine them even brighter.)

Lots of wall space for some singular items, much like you sometimes see in painting galleries.

Striking, wall-sized inset cases with nice lighting.

It's obvious that someone considered the placement of items and cases within the room, breaking up space by orienting occasional cases and objects at perpendicular angles. One of my favorite objects was the carpet below; instead of just tacking it onto the back wall, they placed it in a two-sided glass case that jutted into the rest of the room. There was space for a person to view the front and back sides.

But in addition, the designers also thought of the inter-room experience: if you looked through any doorway you would see a strategically-placed "alluring" item in the room just ahead, there to draw you in. AND those rooms that had to be separated used nicely decorated (automatic) glass doors so you could see to the other side.

There were lights for certain exhibits, too. The default was off, most likely to preserve electricity or item quality, but the viewer could turn the light on.

And finally, there were many coin displays that someone obviously wanted to liven up beyond the usual, flat "numbered grid + legend" format. So there are glass touch screens! (They're actually more accurate than they look in the video below; I was having trouble reaching the correct points on the screen while trying to keep my camera at arm's length.)

So, all my friends who want to go into museum design or just like museums, keep Davids Samling in mind as a prototype. :)
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: The Book of Hamburg
item.content:encoded:
I spoke as much German as possible today, walked around for nine hours, and took nearly two hundred pictures. Here we go.

After buying meinen Kaffee I ambled toward the city center. Just some interesting street sights:

I was on my way to the Rathaus ("City Hall") and happened upon the Hamburger Kunsthalle, a modern art gallery, first. There was such a fantastic Max Beckmann exhibit that it's going in its own post.

After spending around 2 hours in the Kunsthalle, I reprised my journey toward the Rathaus and happened upon this area first. I think it was part of the Aussenalster. Whatever, it was pretty.

Still on my way to the Rathaus, I next ran into Hauptkirche Sankt Petri ("Saint Peter's Cathedral").

Finally, and after a lot of fun wandering in the mall, I hit the Rathaus. It was impressive.

Then more walking. I crossed some bridges, found myself in the university area going through the botanic gardens. And I found a law school.

I decided to turn around and hit up Hauptkirche St. Michaelis ("Saint Michael's Church"), which was a fortunate move. When I walked in the choir was in the middle of their warmups. So I sat for the better part of an hour listening to them rehearse for a concert the following night.

It had been a full day. I started heading back to my apartment and came across a beautiful design store. Mmmm, lights.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Exodus
item.content:encoded:
The trip back to San Francisco objectively was long, but being filled with travel decisions and hyperattentiveness to stations and names, seemed to go by quickly.

In the morning I took two trains from Hamburg back to Copenhagen. The first was a "you should've reserved a seat" train, but after getting bumped from a seat just once I found one in the back of the car that was never occupied. The second was a comfortable train that was only half full.

On this train I happened to witness a family traveling with a boy around 8 years old. He was speaking British English fluently but would switch to perfect French when his parents seemed to want him to. His parents were clearly training him for academia (or just independence), asking him to provide examples when he'd make a claim and reasoning with him when he was bored. Most likely the kid was brilliant.

After another short train ride to the Copenhagen Airport, where I caved and bought duty free chocolate with my last remaining DKK, I finally boarded the plane from Copenhagen to NY. Mmmm, Norwegian Air Shuttle and the Dreamliner again.

This time the flight crew was sassy New York all the way. And this time I had the fortune of sitting next to a very pleasant Danish man who carried on conversation for at least half the flight. I've never had a long flight go by so quickly.

Arrive at JFK. I'm staying in a hotel 6 minutes from the airport because my last flight, from JFK to SFO, is in the morning. My nice, warm bed should be just minutes from me; of course, I have to take the AirTrain first and then wait until the half hour (11:30 PM) for the shuttle to arrive.

Check in. Arrive at room. Not great, but the shower and the bed are completely functional. Fall asleep almost immediately.

And then wake up early! Quick stop for free coffee downstairs, catch the shuttle back to the airport, not long afterwards board the plane, land in SFO.

HOME!

My last flight was reflective and enjoyable, even though/because I purchased the music package for $5. It's apparent that domestic carriers are just completely broke these days. It was a lovely time to think about the travels I'd made and the ones yet to come.

Hoping to carry them on here in my Bay Area home.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Genesis
item.content:encoded:
In the beginning when God created the heavens and the earth,

the earth was a formless void and darkness covered the face of the deep, while a wind from God swept over the face of the waters.

Then God said, "Let there be light"; and there was light.

 

I don't believe in God beyond its existence as a character in folklore, Steinbeck, and convenient arguments against rational thought. Neither does Stephen Hawking. But I always admired the notion that someone could decide to invoke light--of all the minor projects to start with--and simply make it so.*

This quality I admired because many of my own actions are accompanied by no small amount of internal debate. I think myself too far into all sides of an issue until no side wins and I don't have to make a decision. It is a wearisome coping strategy.

Traveling alone after grad school was an intriguing idea that, probabilistically, would go the same direction: vaporizing like a slickly tongued smoke ring in a dusky hookah bar, slipping into the heavy, hanging particulate to be sucked in and blown out anew. But

 

This time Kay said, "Let there be a ticket to Copenhagen"; and there was a ticket to Copenhagen.

 

It actually wasn't like that. Actually, I was talking to my friend Julie and my motor functions did the "Purchase" button on CheapOAir.com while my cognitive functions did Julie. Fortunately, plans are more easily followed through when they are non-refundable.

So here I was, going to The Motherland--and NYC first, and after some planning probably Berlin, too--and I decided like anyone with good Scandinavian genes that I needed to at least be productive while I enjoyed my downtime. Blogging is the most efficient way to be productive while simultaneously documenting your experiences and assuring your parents that you are still alive.

Happy reading.

 

*I like Patrick Stewart, too.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: The Book of Becca
item.content:encoded:
And Becca was amazing.

I met Becca Schneider when we were both twenty years old, studying abroad at Royal Holloway University in Egham, England. There we had three-hour dinners while screaming incredulously about how little work we had to do in English college, had makeshift Pancake Days and Rosh Hashanahs, traveled through Paris, Rome, Florence (ugh), Venice, and Nice together. She's one of the most hilarious and talented people I've ever met, as well as the reason I know ANYTHING about theater.

In fact, Becca's a theater connoisseuse. She sees Broadway and off-Broadway shows at least once a week and does her own reviews on her blog at Becca On Broadway. When we were in England together, she volunteered to help produce and star in what every witness will admit was the sorriest college theater department show ever produced--minus Becca's performance. (We rewatched the recording of that show last night and couldn't stop laughing. The props fell apart and the pit orchestra keyboardist nearly flung his instrument into the audience in a "look at me shine" flourish. England is ridiculous.) Much more recently, Becca fundraised for, produced, and starred in a show called The Understudy--which I'm sure was of infinitely better production value.

Becca can sing. Theater-style, really well. She's a physical comedian with a hyper-expressive face and an uncanny ability to imitate Jerry Blank from Strangers With Candy. In many ways she's a modern Gilda Radner. And she's fun. We had some excellent catching up, and I was reminded of just how creative, exciting, and wonderful Becca is. As evidence, I submit a music video that she and her roommate, Diana, created in a few hours just for the fun of it.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: On the second day
item.content:encoded:
On the second day, there were 25,000 steps.

 

New York is for doers. Prior to this trip I hadn't been to New York in three or four years, and I'd been living away from East Coast cities for a few years. It was excellent to ride the trains (minus the guy who clearly took me as a moron for not knowing that Queens was uptown, not downtown) and walk roughly ten miles in one day. I was speed walking in no time.

First I met up with my friend Natasha, who moved to Princeton, NJ after we finished our masters program this August. We went to City Bakery, home of the delectable pretzel croissant and the dreamy "Chocolate Room" you see below.

After ingesting some delicious sodium, fat, and caffeine, we became tourists. Here's the requisite picture of the Flatiron Building. Did you know that architects decried it as disgusting and horrible upon its dedication? And that given new engineering innovation, it was completed in only one year?


We then hit up the New York Public Library and took a free tour of the building. It's gorgeous. It boasts marble from the same quarry in Greece that fed the Parthenon, as well as red marble from France and several other types of marble. There's a map room with intricate woodwork, and a writing room that holds Charles Dickens' writing desk and Virginia Woolf's walking stick. (And something about an ivory letter opener made from the forepaw of Dickens' beloved cat, Bob.) Natasha and I essentially felt up the entire building while everyone else listened to the tour guide.

Next, Rockefeller Plaza and the Lego store next door. So. Many. Legos.

The International Building in Rockefeller Plaza has a gorgeous light/metal sculpture that casts a golden glow over the entire inside. My photography skills and my camera are unfortunately too deficient to really show this off. But I assure you it was beautiful.

We stopped by the MoMA, but given that we didn't have much time before Natasha needed to head off to a meeting, we settled on perusing the two museum shops on the ground floor. For a long time. :)

After saying goodbye to Natasha, I walked another 50 minutes to meet an old college roommate, Sara, at Kanoyama sushi restaurant in East Village. Catching up with old friends over green tea and sticky rice is really pleasurable. I learned that Sara was now, against all odds, an avid skier.

She's also an inspirational worker in public policy, attempting to work with state legislatures to invest money in programs that reduce jail population and lengths of stay for those awaiting trial, as well as decreasing recidivism. It sounds challenging and heartbreaking; Sara of course loves it.

Perhaps the best part of the day was returning to Becca's place exhausted, catching up with the women in the apartment, and perusing this lovely calendar that had arrived free and completely unexplained in Becca's mail that day.

Aaah, New York.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Tivoli Halloween
item.content:encoded:
After a nice nap, I wandered around Copenhagen to figure out the landscape. At over 1 million occupants it's by far the largest city in Denmark, but it does feel fairy small. Some parts feel like areas of London, whereas most others feel and look like those in a much smaller city.

Aaaah, Danes. They're generally tall, light-haired, blue-eyed. About 87% of them where designer glasses. Fifty-six percent of them ride bicycles rather than driving cars (I later found out that one of the many reasons for this is the 180% tax on purchased cars). And at least 90% of them wear one or more black articles of clothing at any time.

They all looked familiar, like various members of my family and all the midwesterners I was exposed to early in life. And since basically everyone in the younger generations is pretty much fluent in English, I felt fairly comfortable in the city right away.

I wandered for a while before deciding to head back to my apartment. But on the way I encountered a large group of people headed the opposite direction. So I followed them. They were going to Tivoli Gardens, the second oldest amusement park in the world, which was having a pre-opening event that night and which was all decked out for Halloween.

Mmmmm, carnival food. I got a falafel pita and watched the Danes enjoy themselves.

A few things are quickly striking about the citizens of Copenhagen. First is their pretty homogeneous appearance, but second is that they are so often with family and friends. Danes of course live under the security of knowing that the government has their basic needs permanently covered. In the absence of strife about money--either overcoming poverty or becoming rich--people work more reasonable hours and thus spend more time with family and friends around town. And given the government assistance for childcare and paid maternity and paternity leaves, you see many young women and men with young children. This was all especially clear at Tivoli that night--a Thursday--when people young and old stayed out just to enjoy the first night of Halloween season.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Exploration: slotte og kirker ("castles and churches")
item.content:encoded:
And Kay wandered the desert for 40 days and 40 nights, or at least it felt like that.

 

On Friday I woke up feeling revitalized after a much-needed 11 hours of sleep. Quickly planning the early part of the day, I took some pictures of my Google Maps to access while I was out and then set out for the first several sight-seeing opportunities.

I have an admittedly underdeveloped sense of direction, and directions are one area where my normally logical thought processes tend to fail. Given these facts and the addition that I have no ability to refresh Google Maps while I'm out, it wasn't surprising that the first place I actually visited was something I stumbled upon after getting slightly detoured from my planned path.

Christiansborg Slot ("Christiansburg Castle")! Here are a few snaps of the outside. I took the last picture just to show off the position of the sun at noon. Aaahhh, Scandinavia.

The castle interior boasts a large hall that served as the reception room, a tower (which has a "lumber room" once used for storing lumber and now storing models of different parts of the castle), stables and a riding area, and ruins/tombs.

I went up to the tower and had to go through a metal detector first. In retrospect, I wonder whether they're afraid of sniping from the tower apex (it's not that tall), as there's nothing else up there that needs security. Views of the city from the top of the tower:

After Christiansborg Slot, I managed to make it to my original destination of Amalienborg Slot. It was, you know, really similar. (The domed building is neighboring Frederiks Kirke, seen later.) Look at the guards!

After the palace I entered Frederiks Kirke ("Frederick's Church") one of the many kirker in the city. I've seen my fair share of western European cathedrals, and for good reason they are all pretty similar. A bit surprising in this particular church were the prominent paintings of wildlife around the dome. Most cathedrals boast saints and other icons rather than animal life.

Later in the afternoon I wandered into Christiana, which my housemate had advised me to go see but which I hadn't researched at all. I had no clue what it was and didn't expect the "freetown" that I found. This seems to be the anarchist/punk/grunge/purposely lawless or homeless area of Copenhagen. It's the kind of area I'd know how to do in West Philadelphia or Queens, but I had trouble reading the situation in a foreign city. I have no pictures from inside because by the time I'd made it through the "Green Light District" (weed shanty town) I'd decided to get out without calling more attention to myself. Here, have some pictures of a one-eyed cat I saw along the way.

My afternoon of sightseeing was topped off by what may have been the best part: a visit to the Danish Design Museum. This part deserves its own post, not least because I took approximately 200 pictures of the items inside....
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Designmuseum Danmark
item.content:encoded:
Lo, there were so many awesome chairs.

 

These days Designmuseum Danmark is a museum showcasing the work of the famous 20th-century Danish designers and architects, but in the early 20th century it was actually an institution for teaching these trades. Many of our aesthetic directions in products from furniture to motorcycles were influenced by the work of the Danish masters who attended.

Currently the major exhibit is devoted to Hans J. Wegner, a seminal furniture designer/artist, and his contemporaries. And since the chair is an item that beautifully exemplifies Wegner's aesthetic arc, the exhibit primarily features chairs and chaises. The museum even made replicas of some of the most famous and interesting pieces for the public to lounge in! But there were plenty of other pieces to view, as well.

Are you ready for about 200 pictures? Because I took a picture of at least half the collection. Because oh my god furniture design.

Let's start with a look at some of the whole-room exhibits.

Beautiful. Now that you have the larger pictures, let's move on to singular objects, starting with household items.

Love it. There were plenty of lights, too. Light design is one of my favorite things in the world.

All right, I think you're now warmed up enough for the chairs. Take a deep breath and dive in.

What makes these chairs examples of gorgeous design? Besides the variety and personality of the holistic pieces, sometimes it is the exquisite caning. I was impressed by the variety of patterns, thicknesses, widths, materials, and placements (some almost completely flush with the wood, as below).

Often it is the perfect curvature of solid pieces of wood.

Very frequently it is the UTTERLY SEAMLESS joints: sometimes intentionally eye-catching, and other times all but invisible.

Or the delicate inlays that add interest.

And finally, sometimes it's the ingenuity of the manufacturing and shipping process. Behold the precursor to Ikea:

As you can infer, I was completely enthralled by Designmuseum Danmark and the beauties inside.

Bonus note: it's pretty clear from the above that I was going around examining and taking pictures of nearly everything. And I was the only one. A very obvious difference between Danes in public places and Americans in public places is that Danes do. not. take. pictures. In fact, I can still count on one hand the number of Danes I've seen even holding a cell phone (or actual camera) in a public building. No matter how Danish I look, there's no hiding my American compulsion for mediocre documentation.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Kulturnatten ("Culture Night")
item.content:encoded:
And the people did celebrate.

 

By sheer force of luck--certainly not by careful research--I happened to be in Copenhagen during their annual Kulturnatten celebration. Culture Night is a single evening per year on which the huge majority of public buildings and many shops open their doors from 6 PM to midnight so that the public can partake in special demonstrations and events. You can purchase a Kulturnatten badge from virtually anywhere for only 90 krone (around $15 USD); this gets you into every building/event and guarantees you free public transportation to and from it. It's a fantastic way to keep citizens involved in their community and civic institutions.

There's even a Kulturnatten app (iOS and Android! Danish and English!) that helps you select your preferred events. And you'll have to select carefully, since there are far too many places to visit than you can possibly get to in six hours.

And here's what I saw.

  • Ingenioerforeningen, or IDA ("Danish Society of Engineers"). They had interactive science- and tech-related exhibits and hourly lectures by theoretical physicist Holger Bech Nielsen. I went for the lectures, hoping they would be in English since many are, but alas.
  • Nationalmuseet ("National Museum"). There was a special exhibit on fur and its uses for clothing, both by native populations and in style. It revolved around opinions of ethics in a way that you don't see in American museums.
  • Raadhus ("Town Hall"). This housed the beautiful piece of cog work that is Jens Olsen's World Clock. And in the main hall, there was a gigantic floor map of Copenhagen and citizens were encouraged to put stickers where they live. Lots of kids' activities, too (like table tennis and toys related to recycling and civic responsibility :D ).
  • 7/11. Snack break. Along with half of the other young people in the entire area.
  • Botanisk Have ("Botanical Gardens"). The gardens are large, and they had many separate areas set up. One was a series of tents set up for hands-on biology experiments and observation.
  • There was also a live light performance in the main greenhouse. Unknowingly, I followed some people through a door that was supposed to be for staff only and saw first-hand that the lights were controlled by actual human beings pushing lights around on moving carts. Then I got shooed out.
  • And there was a series of live concerts. Not sure who this was, but it was fun to listen to.
  • Also some other light setups in the botanical garden.
  • Geologisk Museum ("Geological Museum"). The basic exhibits were open.
  • Davids Samling ("The David Collection"). A museum founded by C.L. David, it houses his original collection of Danish, Islamic, and European art, porcelain, books, and other goods. I loved the exhibit design so much that I'll write a separate post on it for my design peeps.

So in the span of nearly six hours and by paying only $15 I visited a large number of cultural institutions, and saw the Danish populace, that I would otherwise never have seen.

Bonus note: at this city-wide night event there was no visible police presence and I saw zero incidents and zero drunk people. Responsible people, these Danes.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: On the eighth day
item.content:encoded:
On the eighth day, there was much travel and seats were reserved.

I took my leave of Copenhagen via the central train station and headed for Hamburg. On the ICE the ride lasts 4.5 hours, some of which is due to delays on the ferry.

What's that? A ferry? I thought you said a train.

There's water separating Copenhagen from mainland Germany, so this high-speed train actually BOARDS A FERRY AND RIDES IT TO THE OTHER SIDE like some sort of adorable Thomas the Tank Engine.

Once the train had mounted the ferry, we were asked to leave the train and go up to the main ferry decks to partake in smoking, dining, shopping, and localized merriment. Even on a large boat the rocking and rolling were noticeable. After less than an hour we were across and were asked to re-board the train, which continued into Hamburg via boring land.

Time for complaining! Deutsche Bahn and the Danish trains allow you to purchase a ticket without reserving a seat. On one of these lines, purchasing a ticket guarantees that a seat will be available to you because they won't oversell; on the other line, you have to actually reserve the seat in order to guarantee it. And I can't remember which is which.

Well, it appeared that most people on the DB train today hadn't reserved a seat, because people were simply picking open seats in a rush.

Now, there were two passengers in my same car who I knew didn't speak German (or Danish). One was a man who approached me on the train platform, pointed to his ticket and then the train, and asked "Hamburg? 2?" in very limited English. The other was a woman across the aisle from me who had the slow reactions of someone who was carefully watching everyone else to figure out what to do; she spoke in English when a man helped her with her bag.

Back to the seat reservations. The train makes several stops along the way, meaning that passengers boarding late in the journey may have reserved seats already gratefully claimed by someone early on. This happened over the German border. Two starchy women boarded, inching up the car as they squinted at their tickets and back up at the posted seat numbers. They recited the seat numbers in German every time.

Finally, they identified the first seat: it was the one sat in by the unfortunate broken English guy who obviously spoke NONE of the languages recited on the train and definitely didn't understand why the older German woman was booming at him about her reservation ("This seat is reserved. You must get up!" she exclaimed, like it was a physical rule that no human could alter). He got up and fled.

Then the second seat: it was two rows up and just across the aisle from me. That's right! The woman who spoke no German. The second German woman loudly addressed her, and when the woman didn't understand, a German passenger next to her volunteered her own seat and came and sat in an empty seat directly across from me.

Yep, there were some empty seats. But apparently you shouldn't mess with one that is (entirely unbeknownst to you) reserviert.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: Max Beckmann and the Hamburger Kunsthalle
item.content:encoded:
My favorite art exhibitions focus on only one artist throughout his career. Visual appeal is necessary, but art is most interesting when it lets you infer the artist's process. You should be able to reverse-engineer the person from the piece.

The Max Beckmann exhibit, featuring oils, watercolors, and household objects used for his still lifes, and spanning primarily from 1921-1945, is a perfect example. Compare one of Beckmann's 1920s paintings with one from the 1940s.

And now, an onslaught of oils from earlier to later work. The first is from 1906; the last I believe is in the late 1940s.

The change in palette is tremendous, as is the evolution from attempted realist representation to things being rough and chunky. Thoughts of war (Beckmann served in WWI and became an expat in Amsterdam in the 1940s, and had to use blackout curtains) and mortality (heart problems) toward the end. But I also love that you can see the same objects recurring in many paintings. Here's a pictures of a still life with the porcelain toad sculpture that inspired it.

The Kunsthalle likewise had the conch shell that shows up in numerous paintings and the vase with snake. No mirrors, fish, or pears, though.

Here are some of Beckmann's watercolors. Sometimes he used pencil for the outlines, whereas other times he went over the lines with black ink or black watercolor. They have a much different tone to them than his oils.

Now enough about Beckmann. The museum featured works by other artists, too.

And there were paintings from the 15th and 16th centuries. I don't do well with paintings from the 15th century and earlier because I spend all my time thinking about how ridiculous the subjects look. For example:

The museum also featured a fair amount of ultra modern art. The worst was an audio recording of a man and a woman reciting every year from 2 million BC to the present. Ugh. I leave you with the better pieces, below.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com

item.title: More of Hamburg
item.content:encoded:
Hamburg, like other European cities, has a historical aesthetic with the toppings of any other international metropolis. On my last few days in the city I took many pictures while roaming.

Outside a public library in Altstadt:

Just one of the many canal areas in the Hafen City area.

One of the absolute most ingenious things I've ever seen: the Elbphilharmonie Hamburg. This is a cubic building with tubes protruding from it. Each tube plays a different symphonic piece or sound, and some play tiny videos inside.

The upcoming Hamburg Philharmonic building, plus a few of the more beautiful canal views:

And many shots of the Planten un Blomen ("Plants in Bloom") botanic gardens.
item.dc:creator: kaychristensen@gmail.com
